<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">

</p>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: bottom" valign="bottom" width="33%">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>In an episode of <em>Seinfeld</em>, the characters discuss whether days of the week have “feels.” Kramer says, “It feels like Tuesday.” Newman responds that it’s in fact Thursday. “Tuesday has no feel.” </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Wrong. As humans molded the artificial seven-day week out of the natural solar and lunar cycles, all days of the week have “feels,” according to <a href="https://www.thebritishacademy.ac.uk/blog/does-risk-tolerance-change-through-the-week/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new research</a>. Here’s how it works: Our tolerance for risk decreases from Monday through Thursday, then spikes again on Friday.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That has some considerable implications. For example, the US holds its elections on a Tuesday, when we’re feeling pretty risky. Would the “safe” candidates, the incumbents, fare better if we held our elections on a Thursday? Possibly.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Or consider decisions you make in your personal life. If you’re set on quitting your job on a Monday, you might want to check in again later in the week, when your riskiness levels have died down.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I know what you’re all thinking: What about Sunday? I don’t think we need a scientist to tell us how to find the RedZone channel. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">— Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers with...Master Sommelier Ian Cauble
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/10/icebreakers-withmaster-sommelier-ian-cauble?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Ian Cauble, Master Sommelier pours wine into a glass" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83Mjg4L2lhbl9jYXVibGUuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Emma K Morris</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In 2012, <a href="https://www.instagram.com/iancauble/?hl=en" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ian Cauble</a> passed the wine world’s version of astronaut training to become one of only a handful of Master Sommeliers in the world. With just a 5% pass rate, the top wine test has snuffed the dreams of all but 267 people who are able to call themselves true Masters. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Cauble’s journey to the top was detailed in the 2012 documentary, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O4zeyuk8hL8" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Somm</em></a><em>,</em><strong><em> </em></strong>and he has since founded <a href="https://www.sommselect.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">SommSelect</a>, an artisanal online wine retailer. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Morning Brew sat down with Cauble to chat about beer. Just kidding.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What’s the career path of a Master Sommelier?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Most people start by working in restaurants for a very long time—a lot of them for more than 10 years by the time they pass the Master Sommelier exam. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Working in restaurants is quite daunting after a while. You have to show up at 11:00am and you're there ’til 11:00pm, if not midnight. So a lot of people, when they pass the Master’s exam, will take on roles working for a large winery, or perhaps a large distributor doing education for their sales reps. Some people start their own business, like I did.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Where would you recommend someone take an affordable wine trip in the US?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Oregon. The Willamette Valley has some of the best price-to-quality Pinot Noir in the world, and it’s home to really great Chardonnay and Riesling as well.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Why is wine the go-to dinner party gift?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When you go to someone’s house, you don't know what they have. But most people don't have <em>that</em> bottle of wine you found on <em>that</em> shelf in <em>that</em> specific wine shop. It’s a very easy gift and there's usually a great story behind it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Does all red wine age well or just the pricey stuff?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That’s a very complex question. Every bottle of wine has its intended drinking window.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Not all red wine ages well; some of the wines age very poorly. It depends on the acidity of the grapes, on when the grapes were picked, how the wine was fermented, what type of barrel it was put into, and how much oxygen it was exposed to. There are so many variables to it. I would say most wine is not designed to age. The vast majority of all wine should be consumed within three-to-five years after purchase.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What’s the best way to impress your date with a wine order at a fancy restaurant?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Lean on the sommelier and allow them to make your dinner better. Not all of them are there to push how much you're spending on a bottle of wine.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. </em></p>

WORK LIFE
</p>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Making Friends Over Zoom
</h1>
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I joined a new role about 2.5 months ago, and my interactions with my manager and teammates have been purely virtual. Any advice/tips on how to build healthy professional relationships with new teammates?—Tarini</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">One of the many movies I re-watched during lockdown was<em> Office Space</em>, a film that at once made me long for and rue the days of in-person work. Having more recently begun a new job on a fully remote team, where the only radio playing at a “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r4iGo0dqsZE" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reasonable volume</a>” is my own, your question got me thinking about the influence that an increasingly virtual workplace is having on team dynamics.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We tend to malign energy spent on small talk or idle banter, but it’s hard to discount how much those moments “in-between” drive camaraderie. While replicating that virtually is a challenge, embracing your teammates’ remote work lives and inviting them to be engaged in yours can certainly help. This can be as simple as initiating more meaningful conversations: Find & replace “How about all this rain?” with something more thoughtful/individualized. Mastered that? Join (or start) a virtual social space—such as a Slack channel or Teams<em> </em>group—dedicated to your favorite hobby or interest.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Something I’m doing with my current team is a rotating brown bag, whereby we use part of our weekly meeting for a team member to teach us something new. While it wasn’t necessarily the goal of the exercise, the more I’m learning about what my teammates are interested in outside of work, the better I’m able to refine and tailor how I relate to them individually.   </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The good news is that there remains plenty of overlap between the in-person and remote world of relationship building. Reliability still matters, a little empathy still goes a long way, and consistent communication is still key (although you can cancel that 4:30 meeting on a Friday.) Try not to overthink it—it may take longer than you’d like, but if you lead with sincerity and authenticity, healthy relationships will eventually follow.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>"How do you become the best looking (best lit up) person on Zoom, when you don’t have natural light in your office?"—Brandon from Minneapolis</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As someone who <em>relies</em> on poor lighting in order to be the best-looking person on my video calls, I’m probably not the best source of advice on this one. Brew readers, anyone have tips for Brandon?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? Have a lighting rec for Brandon? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Write in here</em></a><em>. </em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>And coming soon...HR Brew. Be one of the </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>first subscribers</em></a><em> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>

<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Your 2021–2022 NFL Season Preview
</h1>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Dwight from The Office running with a football" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=559 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/C0D9AFGOus9TIRA6CF/giphy-downsized-large.gif?cid=ecf05e47o9fiqx2hu7lucilk7fyn6cip6ldblftum4720n2k&rid=giphy-downsized-large.gif&ct=g">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Dwight from The Office running with a football" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/C0D9AFGOus9TIRA6CF/giphy-downsized-large.gif?cid=ecf05e47o9fiqx2hu7lucilk7fyn6cip6ldblftum4720n2k&rid=giphy-downsized-large.gif&ct=g">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Giphy/The Office</em>
</small>
</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The new NFL season kicks off with a full slate of games today. We already know that Tom Brady will be in the Super Bowl—but what are the other major themes this season? Here’s a quick rundown.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">More betting </h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The NFL used to treat sports betting like Midwesterners treat any problem—smile and don’t talk about it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Now, following the Supreme Court’s 2018 decision that allowed states to legalize sports betting, the NFL is crushing hard.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">During the offseason, the NFL struck deals with seven sportsbook operators, which, among other things, allows them to buy commercial spots during NFL games for the first time ever. And buy they will: Sportsbooks are expected to spend <a href="https://frontofficesports.com/football-ads-sports-betting-fanduel-draftkings/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">up to $1 billion</a> on advertising this season. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">They’ll find plenty of customers. More than 45 million Americans expect to bet on the NFL this season, a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/sports-nfl-football-tampa-health-91e74170294fcb1e0e6d1a5ab7be62e4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">36% increase</a> over last year, per the American Gaming Association. That’s because more states than ever (26 plus DC) have legalized sports betting. And as many as five more states could offer it before the 2022 Super Bowl arrives.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Longer season</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">43 years after the NFL expanded from 14 to 16 games in the regular season, it just <a href="https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/31159686/nfl-moves-17-game-regular-season-2021-means-teams-players-revenue-fans?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tacked on</a> one more to hit 17.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The expansion, a result of a new collective bargaining agreement (CBA) signed last year, is a big deal for anyone who loves prime numbers and wants to see NFL-associated businesses rake in the $$$.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Gambling companies will <a href="https://nypost.com/2021/09/08/nfls-17th-game-adds-betting-and-postseason-prestige/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">make more money</a>, football players will make more money, and the NFL itself certainly stands to gain from an extra slot for advertising, ticket sales, merchandise, and more.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The 17-game season means the 2022 Super Bowl will be played on its latest date ever: February 13. Looks like it’s leftover nachos for Valentine’s Day dinner.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">More streaming</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As part of the NFL’s new <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/18/nfl-media-rights-deal-2023-2033-amazon-gets-exclusive-thursday-night.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">gargantuan media rights deal</a> reportedly worth over $100 billion, streaming will play a bigger role. This season, Amazon Prime Video will share the rights with NFL Network and Fox for Thursday Night Football (TNF), but come 2022 you’ll be all Andy Jassy’s: Amazon will be the exclusive “broadcaster” for TNF for the next 10 years.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s a landmark deal that highlights Amazon’s ambitions in live sports, something its streaming rival Netflix has said it isn’t interested in pursuing.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Covid</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Oh yeah, that. Last year, the NFL season had “early-stage pandemic” vibes with cardboard cutouts of fans, coaches wearing masks, and players being yanked from games over Covid-19 protocols.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This season, the NFL is citing vaccinations as a reason to return things to semi-normal. Stadiums will be packed with fans since all 32 teams are opening them up to full capacity to begin the season. But only <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/seattle-seahawks-latest-nfl-team-require-proof-covid-vaccination-or-n1278660?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">three</a> will require proof of vaccination or a negative Covid test to attend home games. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The NFL is also cracking down on teams with unvaccinated players, saying that if a game can’t be rescheduled due to a Covid-19 outbreak among unvaccinated players, that team will <a href="https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-covid-19-outbreaks-unvaccinated-players-forfeit-cancelled-game?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">forfeit</a> the game.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The good news is, as of last week, 17 of the NFL’s 32 teams had vaccinated <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-08/more-than-half-of-nfl-teams-have-immunized-95-of-players?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">95% of their players</a>, and two—the Atlanta Falcons and Tampa Bay Buccaneers—reached 100% immunization. <em>– NF</em></p>

Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that wants to know: If given the chance, would you live in a real-life gingerbread house?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/9TOh5d7iMaVhExJcOx/giphy.gif?cid=790b7611ffd82d96bdda390f1aec1d8b39f515db1d254349&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="3 bed, 2 bath home in Seattle, Washington near Lake Washington with lots of carpet, stained glass, low ceilings, and pastel colors" data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">With views of Lake Washington and Mount Rainier, this Seattle <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/6352-Seward-Park-Ave-S-Seattle-WA-98118/49105188_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">home</a> is the perfect space for anyone who loves the outdoors and pastel walls. The 2,960-square-foot house has criminally low ceilings, but makes up for it with some other amenities:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>3 beds, 2 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Carpet that’s almost </span><span><em>too</em></span><span> textured</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Huge backyard</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Most stained glass in the neighborhood</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much for the opportunity to remake Hansel and Gretel in your own home? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Just Click It
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">1. How a simple email address makes things complicated. (<a href="https://www.vox.com/recode/22620276/what-to-do-when-you-get-someone-elses-email-security-vulnerabilities-gmail-inbox-invasion?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Vox</a>)<br>2. “Fantasy Hollywood”: crypto and community-owned characters. (<a href="https://future.a16z.com/fantasy-hollywood-crypto-and-community-owned-characters/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a16z</a>)<br>3. The power of perspective and prioritizing family and friends. (<a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-power-of-perspective-and-prioritizing-family-friends/id1509276485?i=1000534891757" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Founder’s Journal</em></a>)<br>4. Porno hustlers of the Atari age. (<a href="https://kotaku.com/porno-hustlers-of-the-atari-age-1847622176?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Kotaku</a>)<br>5. Why we can’t shake ambergris, one of the world’s unlikeliest commodities. style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eIn an episode of \u003cem\u003eSeinfeld\u003c/em\u003e, the characters discuss whether days of the week have “feels.” Kramer says, “It feels like Tuesday.” Newman responds that it’s in fact Thursday. “Tuesday has no feel.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWrong. As humans molded the artificial seven-day week out of the natural solar and lunar cycles, all days of the week have “feels,” according to \u003ca href=\"https://www.thebritishacademy.ac.uk/blog/does-risk-tolerance-change-through-the-week/?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew research\u003c/a\u003e. Here’s how it works: Our tolerance for risk decreases from Monday through Thursday, then spikes again on Friday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThat has some considerable implications. For example, the US holds its elections on a Tuesday, when we’re feeling pretty risky. Would the “safe” candidates, the incumbents, fare better if we held our elections on a Thursday? Possibly.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOr consider decisions you make in your personal life. If you’re set on quitting your job on a Monday, you might want to check in again later in the week, when your riskiness levels have died down.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI know what you’re all thinking: What about Sunday? I don’t think we need a scientist to tell us how to find the RedZone channel. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e— Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIcebreakers with...Master Sommelier Ian Cauble\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/10/icebreakers-withmaster-sommelier-ian-cauble?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Ian Cauble, Master Sommelier pours wine into a glass\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83Mjg4L2lhbl9jYXVibGUuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eEmma K Morris\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn 2012, \u003ca href=\"https://www.instagram.com/iancauble/?hl=en\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eIan Cauble\u003c/a\u003e passed the wine world’s version of astronaut training to become one of only a handful of Master Sommeliers in the world. With just a 5% pass rate, the top wine test has snuffed the dreams of all but 267 people who are able to call themselves true Masters. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eCauble’s journey to the top was detailed in the 2012 documentary, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O4zeyuk8hL8\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomm\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e,\u003c/em\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eand he has since founded \u003ca href=\"https://www.sommselect.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSommSelect\u003c/a\u003e, an artisanal online wine retailer. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMorning Brew sat down with Cauble to chat about beer. Just kidding.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat’s the career path of a Master Sommelier?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMost people start by working in restaurants for a very long time—a lot of them for more than 10 years by the time they pass the Master Sommelier exam. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWorking in restaurants is quite daunting after a while. You have to show up at 11:00am and you're there ’til 11:00pm, if not midnight. So a lot of people, when they pass the Master’s exam, will take on roles working for a large winery, or perhaps a large distributor doing education for their sales reps. Some people start their own business, like I did.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhere would you recommend someone take an affordable wine trip in the US?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOregon. The Willamette Valley has some of the best price-to-quality Pinot Noir in the world, and it’s home to really great Chardonnay and Riesling as well.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy is wine the go-to dinner party gift?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen you go to someone’s house, you don't know what they have. But most people don't have \u003cem\u003ethat\u003c/em\u003e bottle of wine you found on \u003cem\u003ethat\u003c/em\u003e shelf in \u003cem\u003ethat\u003c/em\u003e specific wine shop. It’s a very easy gift and there's usually a great story behind it.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDoes all red wine age well or just the pricey stuff?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThat’s a very complex question. Every bottle of wine has its intended drinking window.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNot all red wine ages well; some of the wines age very poorly. It depends on the acidity of the grapes, on when the grapes were picked, how the wine was fermented, what type of barrel it was put into, and how much oxygen it was exposed to. There are so many variables to it. I would say most wine is not designed to age. The vast majority of all wine should be consumed within three-to-five years after purchase.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat’s the best way to impress your date with a wine order at a fancy restaurant?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLean on the sommelier and allow them to make your dinner better. Not all of them are there to push how much you're spending on a bottle of wine.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F09%2F10%2Ficebreakers-withmaster-sommelier-ian-cauble\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI joined a new role about 2.5 months ago, and my interactions with my manager and teammates have been purely virtual. Any advice/tips on how to build healthy professional relationships with new teammates?—Tarini\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOne of the many movies I re-watched during lockdown was\u003cem\u003e Office Space\u003c/em\u003e, a film that at once made me long for and rue the days of in-person work. Having more recently begun a new job on a fully remote team, where the only radio playing at a “\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r4iGo0dqsZE\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereasonable volume\u003c/a\u003e” is my own, your question got me thinking about the influence that an increasingly virtual workplace is having on team dynamics.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe tend to malign energy spent on small talk or idle banter, but it’s hard to discount how much those moments “in-between” drive camaraderie. While replicating that virtually is a challenge, embracing your teammates’ remote work lives and inviting them to be engaged in yours can certainly help. This can be as simple as initiating more meaningful conversations: Find \u0026 replace “How about all this rain?” with something more thoughtful/individualized. Mastered that? Join (or start) a virtual social space—such as a Slack channel or Teams\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003egroup—dedicated to your favorite hobby or interest.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSomething I’m doing with my current team is a rotating brown bag, whereby we use part of our weekly meeting for a team member to teach us something new. While it wasn’t necessarily the goal of the exercise, the more I’m learning about what my teammates are interested in outside of work, the better I’m able to refine and tailor how I relate to them individually.   \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe good news is that there remains plenty of overlap between the in-person and remote world of relationship building. Reliability still matters, a little empathy still goes a long way, and consistent communication is still key (although you can cancel that 4:30 meeting on a Friday.) Try not to overthink it—it may take longer than you’d like, but if you lead with sincerity and authenticity, healthy relationships will eventually follow.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\"How do you become the best looking (best lit up) person on Zoom, when you don’t have natural light in your office?\"—Brandon from Minneapolis\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAs someone who \u003cem\u003erelies\u003c/em\u003e on poor lighting in order to be the best-looking person on my video calls, I’m probably not the best source of advice on this one. Brew readers, anyone have tips for Brandon?\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? Have a lighting rec for Brandon? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWrite in here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnd coming soon...HR Brew. padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nYour 2021–2022 NFL Season Preview\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Dwight from The Office running with a football\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=559 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/C0D9AFGOus9TIRA6CF/giphy-downsized-large.gif?cid=ecf05e47o9fiqx2hu7lucilk7fyn6cip6ldblftum4720n2k\u0026rid=giphy-downsized-large.gif\u0026ct=g\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Dwight from The Office running with a football\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/C0D9AFGOus9TIRA6CF/giphy-downsized-large.gif?cid=ecf05e47o9fiqx2hu7lucilk7fyn6cip6ldblftum4720n2k\u0026rid=giphy-downsized-large.gif\u0026ct=g\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGiphy/The Office\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe new NFL season kicks off with a full slate of games today. We already know that Tom Brady will be in the Super Bowl—but what are the other major themes this season? Here’s a quick rundown.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eMore betting \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe NFL used to treat sports betting like Midwesterners treat any problem—smile and don’t talk about it.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNow, following the Supreme Court’s 2018 decision that allowed states to legalize sports betting, the NFL is crushing hard.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDuring the offseason, the NFL struck deals with seven sportsbook operators, which, among other things, allows them to buy commercial spots during NFL games for the first time ever. And buy they will: Sportsbooks are expected to spend \u003ca href=\"https://frontofficesports.com/football-ads-sports-betting-fanduel-draftkings/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eup to $1 billion\u003c/a\u003e on advertising this season. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThey’ll find plenty of customers. More than 45 million Americans expect to bet on the NFL this season, a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/sports-nfl-football-tampa-health-91e74170294fcb1e0e6d1a5ab7be62e4?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e36% increase\u003c/a\u003e over last year, per the American Gaming Association. That’s because more states than ever (26 plus DC) have legalized sports betting. And as many as five more states could offer it before the 2022 Super Bowl arrives.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eLonger season\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e43 years after the NFL expanded from 14 to 16 games in the regular season, it just \u003ca href=\"https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/31159686/nfl-moves-17-game-regular-season-2021-means-teams-players-revenue-fans?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etacked on\u003c/a\u003e one more to hit 17.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe expansion, a result of a new collective bargaining agreement (CBA) signed last year, is a big deal for anyone who loves prime numbers and wants to see NFL-associated businesses rake in the $$$.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eGambling companies will \u003ca href=\"https://nypost.com/2021/09/08/nfls-17th-game-adds-betting-and-postseason-prestige/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emake more money\u003c/a\u003e, football players will make more money, and the NFL itself certainly stands to gain from an extra slot for advertising, ticket sales, merchandise, and more.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe 17-game season means the 2022 Super Bowl will be played on its latest date ever: February 13. Looks like it’s leftover nachos for Valentine’s Day dinner.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eMore streaming\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAs part of the NFL’s new \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/18/nfl-media-rights-deal-2023-2033-amazon-gets-exclusive-thursday-night.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egargantuan media rights deal\u003c/a\u003e reportedly worth over $100 billion, streaming will play a bigger role. This season, Amazon Prime Video will share the rights with NFL Network and Fox for Thursday Night Football (TNF), but come 2022 you’ll be all Andy Jassy’s: Amazon will be the exclusive “broadcaster” for TNF for the next 10 years.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s a landmark deal that highlights Amazon’s ambitions in live sports, something its streaming rival Netflix has said it isn’t interested in pursuing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eCovid\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOh yeah, that. Last year, the NFL season had “early-stage pandemic” vibes with cardboard cutouts of fans, coaches wearing masks, and players being yanked from games over Covid-19 protocols.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis season, the NFL is citing vaccinations as a reason to return things to semi-normal. Stadiums will be packed with fans since all 32 teams are opening them up to full capacity to begin the season. But only \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/seattle-seahawks-latest-nfl-team-require-proof-covid-vaccination-or-n1278660?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethree\u003c/a\u003e will require proof of vaccination or a negative Covid test to attend home games. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe NFL is also cracking down on teams with unvaccinated players, saying that if a game can’t be rescheduled due to a Covid-19 outbreak among unvaccinated players, that team will \u003ca href=\"https://www.nfl.com/news/nfl-covid-19-outbreaks-unvaccinated-players-forfeit-cancelled-game?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eforfeit\u003c/a\u003e the game.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe good news is, as of last week, 17 of the NFL’s 32 teams had vaccinated \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-08/more-than-half-of-nfl-teams-have-immunized-95-of-players?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e95% of their players\u003c/a\u003e, and two—the Atlanta Falcons and
